items.Description: It is referred to as the 'Telugu New Year'. Ugadi in Telugu means New Year.
Celebration of the birth of Lord Rama, the seventh incarnation of Lord Vishnu.
A significant day in Hinduism observed with fasting and prayers.
A puja performed by married Hindu women to seek the blessings of Mahalakshmi, goddess of wealth and prosperity.
Celebrated as the arrival of Lord Ganesha on earth.
The nine-day festival of Durga culminating in Vijayadashami, celebrating the victory of good over evil.
The Hindu celebration of good over evil, marking the end of Navaratri.
Observed by Muslims, celebrated across Sufi shrines known as Ashurkhana.
Celebrated by married Hindu women for the health and long life of their husbands.
Known as the 'Festival of Lights', celebrating the victory of light over darkness.
A festival celebrated on the full moon day of the Kartika month, dedicated to Lord Shiva.
The first day of the Sankranti festival, where old items are discarded and burned in a bonfire, symbolizing new beginnings.
A major harvest festival marking the transition of the Sun into Makara Rasi (Capricorn).
The third day of the four-day Sankranti festival, dedicated to cattle worship.
Celebrates Lord Shiva with night-long prayers and rituals.
A festival celebrating the bond between brothers and sisters.
A folk festival dedicated to Goddess Mahakali, especially celebrated in Telangana and some parts of Andhra Pradesh.
A grand celebration of Lord Ganesha's birth.
Celebrated by Christian communities, commemorating the birth of Jesus Christ.
Celebrated by the Muslim community, marking the end of Ramadan.
Known as the festival of sacrifice, celebrated by the Muslim community.
A harvest festival celebrated mainly by Tamil-speaking communities.
A festival to worship snakes, seeking blessings for the family’s well-being.
Celebrated to honor the birth of Lord Hanuman.
Harvest festival marking the transition of the Sun into Makara Rasi; celebrated with traditional activities such as kite flying.
Marks the birth of the Sun God, celebrated with processions, especially in Tirumala.
An annual fair held at the Lakshmi Narasimha Swamy Temple in Antarvedi, attracting thousands of pilgrims.
Celebrated on the eve of Maha Shivaratri at Kotappakonda, known for the giant 'Prabhas' procession.
An annual folk festival in Tirupati where devotees offer food and sarees to Goddess Gangamma.
A cattle trading festival in Vizianagaram, featuring various stalls and performances.
A three-day festival at the Bara Shaheed Dargah in Nellore, attended by people across religious lines.
A cultural festival in Visakhapatnam showcasing arts, crafts, and cuisine of the region.
A floral festival celebrated predominantly by women, involving the preparation of flower stacks and traditional songs and dances.
Celebrates the state's Buddhist heritage, with events held in Nagarjunasagar and Amaravati.
Held in Hyderabad, showcasing the arts, crafts, and culture of the Deccan region.
A traditional festival celebrated on the third day of the Sankranti festival (Kanuma) in the Konaseema region.
A nine-day annual festival at the Venkateswara Temple in Tirumala, attracting pilgrims worldwide.
A festival celebrated by the Nyishi tribe to invoke the blessings of spirits for prosperity and harmony.
The New Year festival of the Monpa tribe, marked by rituals to drive away evil spirits and welcome prosperity.
An agricultural festival of the Adi tribe, involving rituals to ensure a good harvest and community well-being.
Celebrated by the Hill-Miris tribe to seek prosperity and a good harvest.
A contemporary music festival held in Ziro Valley, showcasing independent artists from across the country.
An agricultural festival of the Nocte tribe, marking the end of the harvesting season.
Celebrated by the Galo tribe to drive away evil spirits and seek prosperity.
A cultural festival promoting the traditions of Arunachal Pradesh and neighboring Myanmar.
A festival of the Idu Mishmi tribe, involving elaborate rituals to appease deities.
Celebrates communal harmony and eco-tourism, featuring traditional sports and cultural performances.
An agricultural festival of the Apatani tribe, praying for a bumper harvest and protection from pests.
Celebrated by the Khamti tribe, marking the New Year with the ceremonial bathing of Buddha statues.
A monastic festival in Tawang Monastery, aiming to ward off evil spirits and bring prosperity.
A festival promoting the culture and traditions of the Sherdukpen tribe.
Celebrated by the Tagin tribe to appease the earth and sun deities for prosperity.
A unique festival combining music and adventure sports, held in Dambuk.
Celebrated by the Digaru Mishmi tribe around February 15 each year
items.Source: this festival involves prayers to the Gods of Earth and Water for protection and prosperity.

items.Description: A celebration of friendship among the Apatani tribes in Ziro
items.Source: held in the last ten days of March. It includes rituals for a fertile harvest and showcases traditional dances and cultural performances.

items.Description: An annual event held in October that celebrates the culture and heritage of Arunachal Pradesh, featuring colorful dances, traditional cuisine, games, and cultural fairs.

Celebrated in the fourth month of the lunar calendar, typically around May or June, this festival commemorates the birth, enlightenment, and passing into Nirvana of Lord Buddha. Devotees engage in religious activities, including visiting monasteries, offering prayers, and participating in rituals aimed at accumulating merit.
A cultural festival showcasing the traditional dance and music of Assam.
A harvest festival celebrated by the Mising tribe, marking the beginning of the sowing season.
A significant Hindu festival held at the Kamakhya Temple, celebrating the fertility of the goddess.
A local festival dedicated to the worship of the goddess Apeswari, involving traditional rituals.
Celebrated by the Rabha tribe, this festival is held to appease the goddess of wealth and ensure a good harvest. It involves traditional dances, rituals, and community feasts.
Celebrated by the Bodo-Kachari tribe in April, it marks the beginning of the new year. The festival is characterized by singing, dancing, and rituals to worship cows and the deity Bathou.
A traditional Assamese theatrical performance combining drama, music, and dance.
An important religious festival of the Bodo-Kachari people, dedicated to the worship of Bathow Bwrai (Lord Shiva). The rituals involve traditional offerings and prayers for community well-being.
A festival of the Deshi people, it is a celebration of sowing crops. The Beshoma starts on the last day of Chaitra and continues until the sixth of Baisakh.
A folk dance festival celebrated by the Bhateli community, showcasing their vibrant culture.
The most prominent Assamese festival celebrating the Assamese New Year and the harvest season.
The first of the three Bihu festivals, marking the Assamese New Year and the onset of spring.
Celebrated by the Deori tribe in mid-April, this spring festival marks the Assamese New Year. It features traditional dances, songs, and rituals to welcome the new year.
A traditional dance form performed during the Bohag Bihu festival.
A cultural festival held on the banks of the Brahmaputra River featuring music and arts.
A festival celebrating the culture and heritage of the Brahmaputra region.
A festival celebrating the end of the agricultural season and the beginning of festivities.
A traditional festival celebrated by various tribes in Assam with dances and rituals.
A post-harvest festival of the Kuki people, celebrated on the first day of November every year, featuring traditional dances inspired by animals and agricultural techniques.
A significant festival of the Karbi tribe, dedicated to the remembrance of the deceased, involving elaborate rituals, dances, and community feasts.
A three-day annual indigenous Tiwa Community fair held during Magh Bihu at Joonbeel, where tribes engage in barter trade and cultural exchanges.
A festival highlighting the biodiversity and cultural heritage of the Dehing Patkai region.
A Hindu festival marking the end of Holi, celebrating with colorful festivities.
Celebrated in the Barpeta region, this festival involves traditional music, dance, and the playing of colors, marking the arrival of spring.
A major Hindu festival celebrating the goddess Durga, marked by elaborate decorations and rituals.
A local festival celebrating traditional crafts and community gatherings.
A unique festival featuring falconry displays and competitions.
A traditional music and dance festival celebrating Assamese folklore.
A festival celebrating the traditional Assamese handwoven towel, symbolizing respect and hospitality.
Celebrated by the Tiwa community, this festival involves rituals to appease local deities and protect the community from evil spirits. It includes traditional dances, music, and animal sacrifices.
An annual event showcasing theatrical performances from various regions.
A post-harvest festival of the Karbi tribe, marked by traditional dances, songs, and community feasts to celebrate the harvest and seek blessings for future prosperity.

Celebrated by the Bodo community, this festival marks the beginning of the sowing season. It involves rituals to appease the gods for a good harvest, along with traditional music and dance performances.
Celebrated by the Tiwa community, Heleibambe marks the end of the harvest season. It involves community feasts, traditional dances, and rituals to thank the deities for a bountiful harvest.
The festival of colors, celebrated with vibrant festivities and community gatherings.
A harvest festival celebrated by the Assamese community with traditional music and dance.
A three-day community fair held in January, where tribes from the hills and plains engage in barter trade. It also features traditional dance, music, and the display of indigenous culture.
An agricultural festival celebrated by various tea tribes of Assam, dedicated to the worship of Karam, the god of power and youthfulness. It usually takes place between August and September.
A youth-oriented festival celebrating the culture and talents of the Karbi community.

Also known as Kongali Bihu, observed in October-November, it is a more solemn festival focusing on crop protection and worship. Lamps are lit in paddy fields to ward off pests and pray for a good harvest.
A festival dedicated to elephants, featuring parades and conservation awareness.

A significant religious festival of the Bodo community, dedicated to Bathou, their supreme deity. The rituals involve traditional dances, music, and animal sacrifices to seek divine blessings for the community's well-being.
A traditional festival celebrating the bond between communities through rituals and dances.
A Hindu festival celebrating the birth of Lord Krishna with devotional singing and dancing.
The second Bihu festival, celebrating the end of the harvesting season with feasts and festivities.

Celebrated on the river island of Majuli, it showcases the rich cultural heritage of Assam, including traditional dance, music, and crafts. The festival aims to promote tourism and preserve the island's unique culture.
A festival of the Bodo community, honoring ancestors with rituals and offerings.
A contemporary festival featuring modern arts, music, and cultural exhibitions.
A local festival celebrating community spirit with traditional performances and gatherings.
A river festival celebrating the Brahmaputra River with boat races and cultural events.
Observed by the Rabha tribe, Nyada signifies the beginning of the agricultural cycle. The community engages in rituals, dances, and songs to invoke blessings for a prosperous farming season.
Celebrated by the Rengma Naga community in early January, this three-day festival aims to ward off evil spirits and ensure prosperity for the coming year.
The Bengali New Year celebrated with cultural programs and traditional festivities.
A traditional harvest festival celebrated by various indigenous communities in Assam.
Pre-harvest festivals celebrated by the Dimasa tribe. Rajini Gabra is performed to appease the gods for a bountiful harvest, followed by Harni Gabra, which marks the beginning of the harvest season.
A dramatic enactment of the life of Lord Krishna, performed during festivals.
Another name for Bohag Bihu, celebrating the Assamese New Year and spring.
A local festival featuring traditional music and dance performances.

Celebrated by the Karbi tribe in April, it is a ritualistic festival to appease local deities for the welfare of the community and a good harvest. The festival includes traditional dances, songs, and animal sacrifices.

A festival commemorating the birth anniversary of Srimanta Sankardev, a revered saint-scholar and cultural icon of Assam. The day is marked by recitations of his writings, devotional songs (Borgeet), and traditional performances like the Sattriya dance.

Celebrated in the Bansai Buddhist village of Balipathar, Bokajan, from April 14 to 17, this festival involves washing the statue of Lord Buddha with pure water, traditional dances, songs, and community feasts.

Observed by various communities in Assam, Sankranti marks the transition of the sun from one zodiac sign to another. It is associated with agricultural cycles and involves rituals seeking blessings for prosperity.
A harvest festival observed by the Zemi Nagas in the Northern Cachar Hills, organized by the youth and marked by traditional dances and songs.
A festival celebrating the cultural heritage of the Sogra community with dances and rituals.
Celebrated by the Mishing community, this festival marks the end of the harvest season and is characterized by traditional dances, songs, and community gatherings.

Organized between November and January in Jorhat, it celebrates Assam's tea culture. Visitors can explore tea gardens, participate in tea tasting sessions, and enjoy traditional Assamese cuisine and cultural performances.
A cultural festival celebrating the traditions and arts of the Wanshuwa community.
A significant Hindu festival dedicated to the Sun God, Surya, celebrated with rigorous rituals including fasting and offering prayers to the setting and rising sun.
A festival marking the brother-sister relationship, celebrated with folk songs and rituals, particularly in the Mithila region.
A harvest festival marking the transition of the sun into Capricorn, celebrated with feasts and kite flying.
Celebrates the birth, enlightenment, and death of Lord Buddha, with major events in Bodh Gaya and Rajgir.
A traditional festival in the Mithila region, dedicated to the serpent goddess Manasa for protection against snake bites.
A festival celebrated by women for marital bliss and the well-being of their spouses, involving fasting and religious rituals.
A significant fair held in Gaya, where devotees perform rituals for the salvation of their ancestors' souls.
A cultural festival in Rajgir showcasing classical and folk performances, attracting artists from across the country.
One of Asia's largest cattle fairs, held in Sonepur, featuring livestock trading, folk performances, and local cuisine.
A major Hindu festival celebrating the goddess Durga, marked by elaborate decorations, rituals, and cultural events.

A month-long religious festival observed during the month of Shravan (July-August), where devotees, known as Kanwarias, collect holy water from Sultanganj and walk barefoot to Deoghar to offer it to Lord Shiva.
A fasting ritual performed by mothers for the well-being and long life of their children, observed mainly in the Mithila region.
Celebrated in the Mithila region, this festival involves newly married women observing rituals and storytelling sessions over several days, focusing on marital bliss and prosperity.
A Hindu festival celebrating the birth of Lord Rama, marked by fasting, devotional songs, and processions.
An important Islamic festival celebrated by the Muslim community in Bihar, marking the end of Ramadan with prayers, feasts, and charity.

Also known as the Festival of Lights, Diwali is celebrated with great enthusiasm in Bihar. People illuminate their homes with oil lamps, burst fireworks, and perform rituals to honor the goddess Lakshmi, seeking prosperity and happiness.

Known as the Festival of Colors, Holi is celebrated with exuberance across Bihar. People smear each other with colors, sing folk songs, and enjoy festive foods, marking the arrival of spring and the victory of good over evil.
A significant Hindu festival dedicated to Lord Shiva, observed with fasting, night-long vigils, and special prayers in temples across Bihar.

Celebrated primarily by students and educational institutions, this festival honors Saraswati, the goddess of knowledge and arts. Devotees set up idols, offer prayers, and seek blessings for academic success.
Celebrated at the ancient Mundeshwari Temple in Kaimur district, this festival showcases classical music and dance performances, attracting artists and devotees from various regions.
Held in Gopalganj, this cultural festival features folk dances, music, and local art forms, promoting the rich heritage of the region.
Organized in Nalanda, this festival commemorates the birthplace of Lord Mahavira with religious rituals, cultural programs, and exhibitions.
Celebrated in Sasaram, Rohtas district, this festival honors the legacy of Emperor Sher Shah Suri with cultural performances and historical exhibitions.
Held in Patna, this fair is organized on Akshaya Tritiya, featuring religious ceremonies, cultural events, and community gatherings.
Celebrated in Jamui district, this festival is associated with Bhagwan Mahavir Jayanti, featuring processions, prayers, and cultural activities.
Organized in Jehanabad, this festival celebrates Sufi traditions with devotional music, poetry, and communal harmony.
Held in Madhubani, this cultural festival showcases local art, music, and dance forms, promoting the Maithili heritage.
Celebrated in Mahishi, Saharsa district, this festival is dedicated to Goddess Ugratara, featuring traditional rituals and cultural performances.
Organized in Jehanabad, this festival highlights tribal culture with folk dances, music, and traditional art forms.
Held in Bodhgaya, this international festival celebrates the teachings of Lord Buddha with religious ceremonies, meditation sessions, and cultural programs.
Celebrated in Gaya on Makar Sankranti, this festival involves rituals, fairs, and community feasts, marking the auspicious occasion.
Organized in Patna, this festival commemorates the birth anniversary of Guru Gobind Singh Ji with religious processions, prayers, and cultural events.
Held in Banka district during Makar Sankranti, this festival features cultural performances, fairs, and religious rituals at Mandar Hill.
Celebrated in Sitamarhi, this festival marks the birthplace of Goddess Sita with processions, cultural programs, and religious ceremonies.
Held in Parsadham, Jhanjarpur, Madhubani, this festival is dedicated to the Sun God, featuring traditional rituals and cultural performances.
Organized in Siwan on Maha Shivratri, this festival includes religious rituals, fairs, and cultural events dedicated to Lord Shiva.
Celebrated in Maner, this festival honors Sufi saint Hazrat Makhdoom Yahya Maneri with devotional music, poetry, and communal gatherings.
Held in Darbhanga, this festival is associated with the legend of Ahilya and Gautam Rishi, featuring religious rituals and cultural programs.
Celebrated in Sasaram, Rohtas district, this festival involves rituals and cultural events at the Guptadham caves, a significant religious site.
Held at the historic Rohtasgarh Fort, this festival showcases the region's history with cultural performances and exhibitions.
Organized in Bela, Gaya on Maha Shivratri, this festival includes religious ceremonies and cultural events dedicated to Lord Shiva.
Celebrated in Aurangabad, this festival is dedicated to the Sun God, featuring rituals, fairs, and cultural performances.
Held in Bhagalpur, this festival commemorates the ancient Vikramshila University with cultural programs and academic discussions.
Celebrated in Madhepura on Maha Shivratri, this festival involves religious rituals, fairs, and cultural events at the Singheshwar temple.
Organized in Madhubani, this festival showcases the rich cultural heritage of Mithila with folk dances, music, and art exhibitions.
Held in Saharsa, this festival promotes the cultural traditions of the Koshi region with performances, fairs, and local cuisine.
Celebrated in Aurangabad on Maha Shivratri, this festival includes rituals and cultural programs at the Umgeshwari temple.
One of Asia's largest cattle fairs, held in Sonepur during Kartik Purnima, featuring livestock trading, folk performances, and local cuisine.
Celebrated in Rajgir during Makar Sankranti, this fair involves holy dips in hot springs, rituals, and cultural events.
Celebrated in Vaishali, this festival commemorates the birth anniversary of Lord Mahavira with cultural programs, processions, and religious ceremonies.
Held in Darbhanga, this festival showcases the rich cultural heritage of the Mithila region through folk dances, music, and art exhibitions.
Celebrated in Bela, Gaya, during Maha Shivratri, this festival includes religious ceremonies and cultural events dedicated to Lord Shiva.
Held in Aurangabad, this festival is dedicated to the Sun God and features rituals, fairs, and cultural performances.
Celebrated in Bhagalpur, this festival commemorates the ancient Vikramshila University with cultural programs and academic discussions.
Held in Madhepura during Maha Shivratri, this festival involves religious rituals, fairs, and cultural events at the Singheshwar temple.
Organized in Saharsa, this festival promotes the cultural traditions of the Koshi region with performances, fairs, and local cuisine.
Celebrated in Aurangabad during Maha Shivratri, this festival includes rituals and cultural programs at the Umgeshwari temple.
Held in Rajgir during Makar Sankranti, this fair involves holy dips in hot springs, rituals, and cultural events.

Also known as Maithili New Year, Jur Sital is celebrated in the Mithila region to mark the beginning of the new year as per the Maithili calendar. It involves traditional rituals, feasting, and cultural activities.

Celebrated on the fifth day of the Shukla Paksha in the month of Margashirsha, Vivaha Panchami commemorates the wedding of Lord Rama and Goddess Sita. Devotees participate in ceremonial reenactments and rituals, especially in regions associated with their legend.

Ganga Dussehra, also known as Gangavataran, is a festival celebrating the descent of the Ganges to earth. Devotees in Bihar, particularly in the Mithila region, take holy dips in the river and perform rituals to honor the occasion.

Celebrated on the new moon day of the Hindu month Kartik, Kali Puja is dedicated to the worship of Goddess Kali. Devotees perform rituals and offer prayers, seeking the goddess's blessings for protection and prosperity.
A cultural festival organized by the Government of Bihar to showcase the state's art, culture, and heritage, typically held at Dilli Haat in Delhi.

Celebrated in January or February, Basant Panchami marks the arrival of spring and is dedicated to Saraswati, the goddess of knowledge and arts. Devotees, especially students, worship her to seek blessings for wisdom and learning.
Observed by the Christian community in Bihar, Good Friday commemorates the crucifixion of Jesus Christ. It is a day of mourning, prayer, and reflection, leading up to Easter Sunday.
A unique 75-day festival dedicated to Goddess Danteshwari, showcasing tribal rituals and cultural events, distinct from the traditional Dussehra celebrated elsewhere in India.
An annual Hindu pilgrimage held in Rajim, where devotees gather to bathe in sacred rivers and participate in spiritual discourses, often referred to as the 'Prayagraj of Chhattisgarh'.
A vibrant festival representing the folk culture of Chhattisgarh, featuring tribal dances, songs, and handicraft exhibitions, celebrated after the monsoon season.
A tribal festival celebrated by the Gond community, involving processions, traditional dances, and rituals dedicated to local deities, observed between December and March across various villages.
An agricultural festival marking the onset of the sowing season, where farmers worship their bulls and participate in traditional dances and music.
An agricultural festival celebrated to mark the beginning of the planting season, involving the worship of agricultural tools and cattle, along with traditional dances and music.

Celebrated by the tribal communities in Bastar, this festival coincides with Rath Yatra and involves unique traditions, including the use of a fruit called 'Goncha' as a mock bullet in playful activities.
A cultural festival held at the Bhoramdeo temple complex, featuring traditional dance performances, music, and a colorful procession, celebrated in the last week of March.
A cultural festival celebrated in Raigarh, dedicated to the memory of the famous saint and poet Chakradhar Swami, featuring classical music and dance performances.
A popular fair held in Narayanpur, attracting visitors with its colorful stalls selling handicrafts, food, and traditional dance and music performances.
Celebrated by the Oraon tribe to honor the god of fate and destiny, marked by the planting of the Karma tree, traditional dances, music, and feasting.
A unique celebration of the Dussehra festival in Dantewada, known for its elaborate processions, traditional dances, and the worship of local deities.
A significant religious fair held in Champaran, the birthplace of Saint Vallabhacharya, attracting Vaishnav devotees from various regions.
Celebrated annually on November 1st, marking the formation day of the state with cultural events and festivities.
A traditional festival where women pray for the well-being of their husbands, involving fasting and cultural activities.
A harvest festival where communities consume the first produce of the season, expressing gratitude for the harvest.
Celebrated in Bilaspur between January and March, this festival showcases the rich cultural heritage of the region through various performances and events.
Held in Janjgir-Champa from January to March, this fair is a significant religious and cultural event attracting numerous devotees and tourists.
Celebrated in Mainpat-Sarguja in January, this festival highlights the unique traditions and culture of the local communities.
Held in Balrampur in January, this festival is known for its cultural programs and attracts visitors from various regions.
Taking place in Sirpur in February, this heritage festival celebrates the historical and cultural significance of the region.
Celebrated in Bastar in March, this festival is known for its vibrant cultural performances and showcases the traditions of the local tribes.
Held in Rajnandgaon in March, this festival features various cultural events and is a major attraction for locals and tourists alike.
Taking place in Giroudpuri-Balodabazar between March and April, this fair is a significant event for the local communities, featuring religious and cultural activities.
Celebrated in Raigarh between August and September, this festival is dedicated to classical music and dance, attracting artists from across the country.
Observed in Raipur in November, this festival marks the foundation day of Chhattisgarh and includes various cultural programs and exhibitions.
Celebrated on November 28th, marking the day in 2007 when Chhattisgarhi was granted the status of a state language.
A traditional celebration where communities consume the first produce of the season, expressing gratitude for the harvest.
A cultural event that honors the land and environment, featuring traditional rituals and community activities.
A vibrant pre-Lent festival with parades, music, and dancing.
Spring festival featuring colorful parades and traditional folk dances.
Festival of Lights celebrated with fireworks and decorations.
Celebrated with midnight masses, decorations, and festive feasts.
Honoring Lord Ganesha with elaborate installations and cultural events.
Monsoon festival celebrating with traditional music and dance.
Commemorates Jesus' resurrection with church services and festivities.
Traditional harvest festival with vibrant music and dance performances.
Honors the saint with processions and religious prayers.
Celebrates goddess Shanta Durga with rituals and community events.
Showcases Goan folk music and traditional dance performances.
Celebrates Lord Hanuman's birth with prayers and festivities.
Nine-night festival honoring goddess Durga with dances and rituals.
Celebrated with beach parties, fireworks, and live music events.
Honors St. Cajetan with masses and community gatherings.
Kerala-originated festival celebrated by some Goan communities.
Marks harvest season with traditional performances and rituals.
Coastal festivals celebrating maritime culture and traditions.
Localized Goa Carnival variant with unique events and parades.
Commemorates Goa's liberation from Portuguese rule.

items.Festival Name: Feast of Our Lady of the Immaculate Conception
items.Description: Celebrates the Virgin Mary with church services and processions.
Annual commemoration of saint’s death anniversary with rituals.
Honors goddess of knowledge with educational activities and prayers.
Islamic observance with processions and religious gatherings.
Month of fasting and festivities for the Muslim community.
Festival of colors celebrated with vibrant festivities and gatherings.
Harvest festival celebrated by the Malayali community in Goa.
Showcases vibrant tulip displays and floral exhibitions.
Celebrates St. John with traditional music and dances.
Highlights coconut-based traditions and culinary delights.
Honors St. Michael with religious ceremonies and festivities.

items.Festival Name: International Film Festival of India (IFFI Goa)
items.Description: Showcases international and Indian films.
India's largest electronic dance music festival held in Goa.
A multi-cultural festival with music, dance, and art.
Celebrates St. Anne with masses and community events.
Honors St. Lawrence with religious processions and prayers.
Celebrates St. Jerome with church services and festivities.
Honors St. Elizabeth with prayers and community gatherings.

items.Festival Name: Feast of Our Lady of Mount Carmel
items.Description: Celebrates the Virgin Mary with processions and masses.
Honors divine rulers with religious and cultural events.
Celebrates St. Anthony with masses and community events.
Highlights the traditional Goan spirit, Feni, with tastings and events.
Celebrates rice cultivation with traditional performances and exhibitions.
Marks rice harvest with rituals and community gatherings.
Brings together authors and literature enthusiasts for discussions.
Features international and local jazz artists performing live.
Showcases alternative and experimental performances in arts.
Local carnival celebrating regional culture and traditions.
Celebrates the Memon community with cultural events and gatherings.
Agricultural festival celebrating farming traditions and rituals.
Local community festival with traditional dances and music.
Honors the Mangueshi Temple with religious ceremonies.
Music festival featuring various genres and artists.
A grand celebration of Christmas with events across Goa.
Unique silent disco events held at various locations in Goa.
Multiple saint feasts celebrated with religious and cultural activities.
Celebrates mango varieties with tastings and cultural programs.
Showcases Konkani culture through music, dance, and food.
Festive market with crafts, food, and live performances.
Promotes wellness with yoga sessions and workshops.
Celebrates Diwali with Goan traditions abroad.
Highlights Goan heritage through exhibitions and tours.
Celebrates Goa’s beaches with sports and entertainment.
Highlights coconut-based traditions and culinary delights.
Showcases Goa's traditional spirit, Feni, with tastings and events.
Celebrates rice cultivation with traditional performances and exhibitions.
Brings together authors and literature enthusiasts for discussions.
Features international and local jazz artists performing live.
Showcases alternative and experimental performances in arts.
Local carnival celebrating regional culture and traditions.
Celebrates the Memon community with cultural events and gatherings.
Agricultural festival celebrating farming traditions and rituals.
Local community festival with traditional dances and music.
Honors the Mangueshi Temple with religious ceremonies.
Music festival featuring various genres and artists.
A grand celebration of Christmas with events across Goa.
Multiple saint feasts celebrated with religious and cultural activities.
Celebrates coastal culture with traditional music and dance.
Local variations of Diwali with unique Goan traditions.
Marks the mango harvest with festivities and tastings.
Colorful kite flying events along the beaches.
Celebrates St. Lucy with church services and processions.
Honors tuna fishing with seafood dishes and cultural programs.
Promotes environmental awareness with workshops and activities.
Nine-night festival with Garba and Dandiya dances celebrating Goddess Durga.
Makar Sankranti event where skies fill with colorful kites.
Cultural festival in the Rann of Kutch showcasing traditional music, dance, and crafts.
Classical dance festival at the Sun Temple in Modhera.
Celebration of Lord Krishna's birth with devotional songs and dances.
Traditional fair associated with Draupadi's swayamvar, featuring folk dances and music.
Five-day fair at Bhavnath Mahadev Temple during Maha Shivratri.
Held at Ambaji Temple during the full moon of Bhadrapad.
Animal trading fair, especially for donkeys, near Ahmedabad.
Kartik Purnima fair at Shamlaji Temple attracting numerous devotees.
Festival of Lights celebrated with lamps, fireworks, and sweets.
Festival of colors marking the arrival of spring.
Celebration of Lord Mahavir's birth with processions and prayers.
Muslim festival marking the end of Ramadan with feasts and prayers.
Celebration of the bond between brothers and sisters with the tying of rakhis.
Festival celebrating Lord Ganesha's birth with installations of his idols.
Worship of Goddess Durga with elaborate pandals and rituals.
Celebration of Jesus Christ's birth with midnight masses and festive decorations.
Gujarati New Year celebrated with prayers and feasts.
Harvest festival marked by kite flying and traditional sweets.
Marks end of winter; celebrated with bonfires, songs, and dances.
Welcomes spring; kite flying is a major attraction.
Festival of colors; celebrated with zest, especially in areas bordering Uttar Pradesh.
Held in honor of Goddess Gauri; involves processions and songs.
New Year's Day for Punjabis; marks the beginning of the harvest season.
Women fast and abstain from water; observed in the month of Jaishth.
Celebrates the onset of the rainy season; women apply henna and receive new clothes.
Birth anniversary of Lord Krishna; temples witness extravagant celebrations.
Religious festival connected with snake-worship; observed in August-September.
Associated with the epic Ramayana; effigies of Ravana are burned.
Festival of lights; symbolizes the victory of righteousness.
Held at Gopal-Mochan near Bilaspur; associated with sacred tanks.
